abstract: pmc J Glob Infect Dis J Glob Infect Dis 1193 jginfectdis JGID J Global Infect Dis Journal of Global Infectious Diseases 0974-777X 0974-8245 Wolters Kluwer -- Medknow Publications PMC12494316 PMC12494316.1 12494316 12494316 10.4103/jgid.jgid_166_24 JGID-17-131 1 Original Article Sexually Transmitted Infections in Women from a Traditional Quilombola Community in Northeastern Brazil Piancó Elaine dos Santos 1 Carvalho Larissa Helena Sousa Baldez 2 Carvalho Clara Vitória Cavalcante 3 Neto Antonio da Silva Lima 2 Soares Paulo Eduardo Silva 2 Côra Gabriel Rodrigues 4 Machado Rayane Alves 4 de Ribamar Ross Jose 5 Vidal Flavia Castello Branco 1 1 2 3 4 5 Address for correspondence: flavia.vidal@ufma.br Jul-Sep 2025 22 9 2025 17 3 498281 131 138 14 8 2024 09 1 2025 03 2 2025 22 09 2025 04 10 2025 04 10 2025 Copyright: © 2025 Journal of Global Infectious Diseases 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/4.0/ This is an open access journal, and articles are distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 License, which allows others to remix, tweak, and build upon the work non-commercially, as long as appropriate credit is given and the new creations are licensed under the identical terms. Introduction: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) affect approximately more than 1 million people around the world. Specific populations are more predisposed to diseases caused by poor access to health care, especially sexual health. This is the case for Indigenous people and other traditional communities around the globe. This work aimed to evaluate the prevalence of some STIs in traditional quilombola communities in the northern region of Brazil. Methods: A cross-sectional and prospective study was carried out from March 2021 to March 2022 of quilombola women from 5 communities. A questionnaire was applied to collect sociodemographic, behavioral, and clinical information. A gynecological examination was performed to collect cervical cells for oncotic cytology and to detect the agents through polymerase chain reaction analysis. Results: Almost half of the women (48.3%) had at least one sexually transmitted agent. Human papillomavirus (HPV) was the most observed ( P P P P P Conclusions: Almost half of the quilombola women had at least one sexually transmitted agent. HPV infection was the most common. The location of the Quilombola community and women’s profession was associated with the prevalence of STIs. Low monthly income and not being in menopause were associated with a higher prevalence of STIs. Quilombola risk factors sexually transmitted infections vulnerable populations Nil. pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement no pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes I NTRODUCTION Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) can be caused by protozoa, viruses, bacteria, and other microorganisms that are commonly transmitted through oral, vaginal, or anal sexual contact. These infections represent a public health problem, with approximately 1 million people infected daily worldwide.[ 1 2 Economic and cultural factors are associated with a higher rate of STI infection due to lack of knowledge of sexual health, difficulty accessing health services, conservative culture, and poor education, which contribute to the persistence of the sexually transmitted agent and the infection of other sexual partners.[ 3 4 Even within underdeveloped countries, there are specific populations that are in more vulnerable conditions that make them predisposed to diseases caused by poor access to health care, especially sexual health. This is the case for Indigenous people and other traditional communities around the globe.[ 4 5 6 7 Quilombolas are a traditional Brazilian community composed of individuals descended from Africans enslaved between the 16 th th 8 This study was conducted in a region in northeastern Brazil with the second-largest population of quilombolas in Brazil.[ 9 3 8 10 11 Information on the prevalence of STIs among these African-descendant women will contribute to expanding knowledge on the epidemiological profile of these infections, generating support for the implementation of public policies for the control of STIs in vulnerable populations. Therefore, the objective of the work is to ascertain the prevalence and factors associated with STIs in African-descendant women from quilombola communities in the Caxias region, Maranhão, Brazil. M ETHODS Sample size population This work followed the guidelines for reporting observational studies (STROBE) and the Microbiology Investigation Criteria for Reporting Objectively (MICRO) guidelines which contain a selection list of items that should be examined in reports of studies involving human clinical microbiology data.[ 12 13 The study was conducted in a region of northeastern Brazil called Maranhão, located at a latitude of 4°51’32” south and a longitude of 43°21’22” west, at an altitude of 66 m. Maranhão is the second Brazilian state with the largest number of quilombola communities.[ 9 14 15 https://www.surveymonkey.com/mp/sample-size-calculator/ Study design and sites This was a cross-sectional analytical study, with 145 women from six quilombola areas: Cana Brava, Jenipapo, Lavras, Soledade, Lagoa dos Pretos, and Vilarias. All these communities, except Soledade and Vilarias, which are close to the city of Caxias, are located in rural areas.[ 14 15 12 The inclusion criteria were women over 18 years of age, sexually active, and living in the quilombola areas. The exclusion criteria were any mental or cognitive condition that would affect the completion of the questionnaire, bleeding, or uterine diseases that contraindicated the collection of endometrial and ectocervical samples. Also excluded were women who had had a hysterectomy or who used vaginal treatments based on creams, ova, lubricants, or spermicides in the last 48 h, undergoing chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy. Data collection and cervical cytology After understanding and consenting upon acceptance, selected women were invited to participate in the study signed the Free and Informed Consent Form and responded to a questionnaire to collect sociodemographic data and risk factors for STIs. Subsequently, they were sent to an examination room where biological samples were collected for analysis of conventional cervical oncotic cytology. Sampling followed routine clinical practice, and the specimens were classified as community-acquired (CAI).[ 12 A qualified professional read the slides. Sample results and degree of cervical atypia were interpreted according to the Bethesda 2001 system. For molecular analysis, biological samples of the cervix were obtained using a sterile brush of the HC2 DNA Collection Device kit (QIAGEN, Valencia, CA). The brush was immediately immersed in the conservative medium and stored at −20°C. The sampling period was from January 2020 to March 2021. Molecular detection of STI agents The species of microorganisms evaluated were Neisseria gonorrhoeae Chlamydia trachomatis, Trichomonas vaginalis, The conservative medium containing the samples was centrifuged at 3075 g for 10 min, and the samples underwent extraction DNA extraction by Dneasy Blood and Tissue Kit (QIAGEN, Valencia, CA) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. For HPV detection, a Nested-polymerase reaction (PCR) was performed using two pairs of primers specific for the L1 protein of the viral capsid, PGMY09/PGMY11 and GP +5/GP +6.[ 16 N. gonorrhoeae C. trachomatis T. vaginalis 17 18 The amplicons were visualized by electrophoresis on a 1.5 or 2% agarose gel in 1X TBE buffer. Electrophoresis was performed for 60 min at 100 v/cm² in a horizontal tank (Life Technologies, USA). Amplified DNA fragments were visualized on an ultraviolet light transilluminator (BIO-RAD Laboratories, USA). According to the manufacturer’s protocol, HPV-positive samples were subjected to automatic sequencing for viral genotyping using the MegaBACE 1000 sequencer (GE Healthcare, UK) with the BigDyeTM Terminator v3.1 cycle sequencing kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The Chromas program was used for the analysis and alignment of the nucleotide sequences obtained in the sequencing, obtaining electropherograms of HPV DNA sequences present in the samples. To confirm and identify HPV type, the nucleotide sequences of the sequenced samples were compared and submitted to the World Nucleotide Database – Gene Bank, using the BLAST program (NCBI). Statistical analyses All variables are characterized by absolute and relative frequency. The Chi-square test was used to associate with the diagnosis of two sexually transmitted agents, chlamydia and trichomoniasis. Associations were also tested between independent variables and people who were not diagnosed with any STI and those who were infected with only one STI. The odds ratio was calculated to verify the probability that agents occurred for each significant variable in the study. The data were analyzed using SPSS (Statistical Package for the Social Sciences) software Version 22 (IBM Company, Endicott, Nova York, EUA), and a significance level of 0.05% was used throughout. R ESULTS In total, 145 women from quilombola areas were analyzed in the municipality of Caxias, in the state of Maranhão. The percentage of women from quilombola areas evaluated, respectively, was Lavras (38%), Vilarias (15%), Soledade (14%), Canabrava (13%), Jenipapo (13%), and Lagoa dos Pretos (7%). Almost half of the women, 48.3%, had at least one sexually transmitted agent. STI: Sexually transmitted infection The predominant age group was between 30 and 50 years old and there was no statistical association between age and the presence of STIs. Most women’s professions were farmers. This group had the lowest rates of STI infection ( P P In general, Quilombola women had low education. Almost half had only elementary education and 37.9% were illiterate. Women with both STIs tend to have lower levels of education, but it was not statistically significant. Regarding monthly income, women who earned up to 1 minimum wage (approximately $285,96) were the majority and had a higher prevalence of one STI ( P Marital status and color were not associated with the presence or absence of STIs ( P Smoking and alcohol consumption were not predominant habits in this population and were not associated with the presence of STIs. Despite this, only 9 women (6.2%) presented atypia on cytological examination, most of them, ASC-US and only one had a high-grade intraepithelial lesion. No variable was associated with the presence of evaluated STIs [ Table 5 The next phase was statistical analysis using binary logistic regression with the calculation of odds (odds ratio) for the variables that gave significance. A category was taken as a reference (REF) to compare the others. The first analysis was for the variables associated with being negative for both STIs. OR: Odds ratio, CI: Confidence interval D ISCUSSION In this study, the prevalence of four common ISTs was evaluated in the population of quilombola. At least one STI was detected in 48.3% of women. The highest infection was HPV (33.1%), followed by C. trachomatis T. vaginalis N. gonorrhoeae et al T. vaginali C. trachomatis N. gonorrhoeae 8 We observed differences in the prevalence of STIs between the communities analyzed in this work ( P 19 20 21 Decades after the discovery of Brazilian territory (1500), the first enslaved Africans were brought to work in the extraction of natural resources and planting the land. These individuals from different African countries resisted the brutality of the slave regime and ran away to create Quilombos, which were communities formed by slaves who escaped from farms.[ 22 Today, the remnants of the quilombos are called quilombolas.[ 15 23 8 11 14 People generally live in precarious conditions, with low monthly income, lack of basic sanitation, and restricted access to education and health services.[ 8 10 14 According to Dias et al. ( 8 P P Profession appears to be a significant variable in the prevalence of STIs, as does the location of the quilombo. This fact may be due to the specific characteristics of the local population. There are communities in which individuals work as farmers and therefore do not leave the region. On the other hand, there are quilombos where people work outside and may interact with outsiders. Indeed, we observed that women who worked on the land had a lower prevalence of STIs than those who were self-employed (tradespeople, teachers, businesswomen, etc.). In quilombola communities, there is a certain territorial isolation, with sexual activities carried out between members of the same quilombo. We suggest that this increase in prevalence is due to the greater contact of self-employed women with people from nearby cities, as they travel outside the quilombola community to work and may have sexual contact. The sexual behaviors of quilombola women, such as age at the first sexual intercourse, age at menarche, number of sexual partners, and use of condoms, were not related to the prevalence of STIs. However, it is important to note that, as in other studies with this type of population, regular condom use is low and the first sexual intercourse is before 15 years old.[ 8 11 The literature reveals that the prevalence of STIs has increased in women after menopause, especially due to the start of new relationships (divorce or widowhood), the nonuse of condoms, as they considered condoms for contraceptive reasons rather than for the prevention of STIs and an increasing number of sexual.[ 23 24 Unlike the literature, our study reveals that women who were not in menopause had a higher prevalence of STIs than those in menopause ( P 8 It is interesting to note that quilombola women have access to reproductive health services by taking contraceptive pills or injections, or hormone therapy for the menopausal ones. However, there is a need for more efforts in actions aimed at health education in the prevention of STIs among quilombola people. Traditional communities are present worldwide, whether indigenous tribes, Australian aborigines, or other ethnic groups. They all have their own culture, including those related to sexual and reproductive behavior.[ 25 C ONCLUSIONS Almost half of the quilombola women had at least one sexually transmitted agent and HPV was the most common. The location of the Quilombola community and the profession of the women were associated with the prevalence of STIs. Low monthly income and not being in menopause were associated with a higher prevalence of STIs. Research quality and ethics statement This study was carried out according to the Declaration of Helsinki (1964), following the regulations set out in the Brazilian Resolution CNS/MS No. 466/2012 for human research. It was approved by the Ethics and Research Committee (CEP) of the Centro de Estudos Superiores de Caxias-UEMA, No. 2.867.682.
